title: 3-YEAR DOCTORAL POSITON Interaction between defects of different dimensions during silicon solidification for photovoltaic applications
location: Jardin du Pharo 58, bd Charles Livon Marseille, France

job_description: Application deadline: 20 MARCH 2022Starting date: September 2022Name of the laboratory:  IM2NP (Institute of Materials Microelectronics Nanosciences of Provence), UMR CNRS 7334 Thesis advisors:  Nathalie Mangelinck-NoÃ«l & Gabrielle RegulaEmail and address: nathalie.mangelinck@im2np.fr, gabrielle.regula@univ-amu.fr, Campus Saint JÃ©rÃ´me, Case 142, 13397 Marseille Cedex 20, FranceSubject description: Global warming and the exhaustion of fossil energy sources are well-known major issues that have become urgent to tackle. A joint-attack is needed including consumption reduction and development of renewable energies among which the photovoltaic (PV) solar electricity will play a major role, provided that significant progress in terms of efficiency, cost reduction and reliability are achieved.  Among the mass production of materials used to produce solar cells, single or multi-crystalline silicon (Si) ingots still dominate the market. For all fabrication processes without exception, the grain boundaries, dislocations, and impurity contamination control during the solidification step remains a major challenge to improve the electrical properties [1]. Impurities play a major role as they not only modify grain nucleation and competition during solidification [2, 3], but they are at the origin and/or interact with structural defects, ultimately degrading the cell conversion efficiency [4]. The furnace environment and crucible are responsible for most of the light impurity contamination and in some cases for metallic impurity contamination. In addition, impurities can be found in the starting feedstock used for PV applications all the more in the case of the research and industry focusing on recycling of solar cells which is fast developing [5]. Therefore, a thorough understanding of the crystallization mechanisms, of the formation of defects at different scales (from dislocations to grains) and of the complex interaction between growth defects and impurities is needed to control these phenomena during solidification processes. Dislocation dynamics during seed heating (Figure 1.a) or while propagating in the ingot during solidification and dislocation interaction with the solid-liquid interface are some of the main issues which are far from being fully understood. Another major key-issue is the interaction of the grain boundaries with dislocations [1] and small angle grain boundaries (SAGBs) [6]. Recently the MCA (auto-organised growth microstructures) team has demonstrated the effect of carbon (C) on the final grain structure: it is constituted by a higher proportion of high order twins and of random angle grain boundaries compared to the case of low C contaminated samples. Moreover, local deformations are induced by the presence of silicon carbide precipitates, which are at the origin of SABGs formation (Figure 1.b). However, further work is needed to better understand the effect of C and other light impurities on grain nucleation and on the related deformation of the crystal structure. Contamination by silicon nitride is another major subject as it is used as crucible coating in the solidification processes. Its effect on first stages of silicon nucleation [7], on grain structure formation, development of structural defects and electrical properties needs to be further studied. As concern metallic impurities, no significant effect on the grain structure is evidenced in the presence of Cu although it induces a destabilization of the solid-liquid interface (Figure 1.c). Iron is another major metallic impurity that is largely responsible for the red-zone (degraded PV properties) in ingots and which effect on grain formation, solid-liquid interface shape and electrical properties needs to be evaluated in details, and to be compared to the case of Cu contamination.Figure 1. a) In situ X-ray imaging of dislocations in a Si sample during heating. b) Peak position map obtained by RCI (Rocking Curve Imaging) and revealing SAGBs in a Si sample contaminated with C. c) In situ X-ray imaging of the solid-liquid interface of a Si sample contaminated with Cu [3]. In order to answer to these up-to-date issues, the objective of the PhD research work will be to contribute to the understanding of the growth mechanisms, of the structural defect formation (dislocations, twins, SAGBs) and of the interaction of these defects in the presence of relevant impurities selected among light and metallic impurities. To reach these objectives, the PhD student will carry-out and analyse, in situ and time-resolved experiments in a unique device named GaTSBI (Growth at high Temperature observed by X-ray Synchrotron Beam Imaging) developed by the MCA team and run at the ESRF (European Synchrotron Radiation Facility), a large European equipment. GaTSBI is constituted of a high temperature (up to 1800Â°C) directional solidification furnace coupled to X-ray imaging. The latter allows studying the shape and dynamics of the solid-liquid interface, the formation and developments of structural defects and of the deformation of the crystal structure [8] in situ during heating of the seeds, solidification and cooling down. The PhD student will also implement ex situ complementary characterisation techniques of the grain structure (EBSD - Electron BackScatter Diffraction), of defects and deformation (RCI-Rocking Curve Imaging [9]), of impurities (TEM, SIMS), or of the electrical or PV properties. The PhD work will be conducted at IM2NP in the MCA team of the Mater Department (Structure and chemistry of materials) in collaboration with: the ESRF (European Synchrotron Radiation Facility), the MSMP (Mechanics, Surface, Materials and Processes) laboratory and the NTNU (Norwegian University of Science and Technology). Funding: Doctoral contract (salary)Keywords: silicon, photovoltaic, X-ray imaging, solidification, impurities, grain boundaries, dislocations, precipitates, twinning.References:[1] G.
